newsArray.title: Australia beats India to win Cricket World Cup for sixth time
newsArray.description: AHMEDABAD, NOVEMBER 19Australia won the Cricket World Cup for a record-extending sixth time Sunday, ending India's dominant run in its home tournament with a six-wicket victor...
newsArray.content: Australia won the Cricket World Cup for a record-extending sixth time Sunday, ending India's dominant run in its home tournament with a six-wicket victory in a low-scoring final on the back of Travis Head's 137. A heavily pro-Indian crowd inside the 132,000-capacity Narendra Modi Stadium was silenced as Head combined with Marnus Labuschagne (58 not out ) in a 192-run partnership to chase down the target of 241. Australia was wobbling on 47-3 after seven overs but Head and Labuschagne dug in to help their country regain its status as the king of one-day international cricket, adding to its 50-over world titles in 1987, 1999, 2003, 2007 and 2015. Head was dismissed off what proved to be the next-to-last ball of the match, caught in the deep while attempting to hit a title-clinching boundary. In came Glenn Maxwell and he ran two off his first ball, securing a victory that prompted fireworks above the world's largest cricket venue. The Indians won all 10 of their matches before the final and were seeking a third trophy in their fourth appearance in a title match that brought a country of 1.4 billion people to a virtual standstill. They were outplayed in every department by Australia, though, restricted to 240 all out on a slow pitch after losing the toss with only Virat Kohli (54) and Lokesh Rahul (66) making half-centuries. Head became only the seventh player to score a century in a men's World Cup final ‚Äì and third Australian after Ricky Ponting and Adam Gilchrist ‚Äì and delivered a significant moment in India's innings when taking a diving catch running back from cover to remove captain Rohit Sharma (47). Head's ton saw him join an illustrious list, which also comprises West Indies' Clive Lloyd and Viv Richards, as well as Sri Lanka's Aravinda de Silva and Mahela Jayawardene. Ponting's 140 not out had also helped Australia beat India in the 2003 final. Jayawardene's century is the only one in a losing cause with India winning the 2011 final. Australia finished the 2023 tournament with a run of nine straight wins, after starting with back-to-back defeats to India and South Africa. India won the World Cup in 1983 and 2011. Its last major success was winning the ICC Champions Trophy in 2013.

newsArray.title: Top of the mountain ‚Äì Pat Cummins hails Australia‚Äôs record sixth World Cup win
newsArray.description: Travis Head‚Äôs brilliant 137 ensured Australia stunned hosts India in Ahmedabad.
newsArray.content: Triumphant Australia captain Pat Cummins basked in his side‚Äôs World Cup triumph over hosts India, capping a remarkable year by reaching ‚Äúthe top of the mountain‚Äù. Australia arrived in Ahmedabad as underdogs, with the home side boasting a perfect record of 10 wins en route to the final, a monster crowd of over 110,000 roaring them on and familiar conditions. They even had the tournament‚Äôs top-scorer in Virat Kohli and leading wicket-taker in Mohammed Shami, but were unable to match Australia‚Äôs ability to stand tall in knockout cricket. Travis Head took the starring role with a brilliant 137, making light work of India‚Äôs under-powered 240 all out, as a six-wicket win made his country six-time champions. It also capped a great year for Australia across red and white-ball cricket, having also pipped India to the World Test Championship crown in June and retained the Ashes with a 2-2 draw on English soil. Reflecting on a stunning sequence of results for his side, Cummins said: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs crazy. This year will be a year we remember for a long, long time. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been awesome. We‚Äôve pretty much spent the whole Australian winter away playing overseas but we‚Äôve had a lot of success and this pips it all. Top of the mountain. We saved our best for last. ‚ÄúThe passion in India is unrivalled around the world. Every single person here was wearing that blue shirt and whatever the result we were never going to forget a day like today.‚Äù Cummins had a fine day at the office. He made the bold and inspired decision to send a power-packed Indian batting line-up in after winning the toss and then produced a superb, boundary-less 10-over spell that included the key wicket of player-of-the-tournament Virat Kohli. But he was happy to give Head his moment in the limelight, as well as sharing with some of the backroom boys who helped him reach the final after he suffered a broken left hand. He was not fit until their fifth match of the tournament and was not even in India when Australia lost their first two group games. ‚ÄúTrav does what he does. He‚Äôs really brave, he takes the game on, puts pressure on bowlers and to do it on the biggest stage showed huge character,‚Äù Cummins said. ‚ÄúIt was amazing. We couldn‚Äôt be happier for Trav, he‚Äôs a legend and we love him‚Ä¶ how fun is he to watch? ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs also on the unheralded few, the selectors that backed him in even when he had a broken hand and the medical team to get him back out there. It was a big risk that we took and it paid off.‚Äù Head was struggling to take in the scale of his achievement, with each of his four sixes and 15 fours stamping down the hopes of the hordes of over a billion Indians. He had earlier taken a cracking over-the-shoulder catch to remove India skipper Rohit Sharma in full flow. ‚ÄúNot in a million years (could I have imagined this)‚Ä¶ what an amazing day. I‚Äôm thrilled to be part of it,‚Äù he told Sky Sports. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a lot better than sitting on the couch at home (injured). I was very lucky to get back here. ‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt imagine getting a hundred, I couldn‚Äôt imagine holding on to that catch‚Ä¶ but you want to help your team-mates and contribute so to do that on a big stage in front of a full house, under all that pressure, is something I‚Äôll be able to look back on all my life.‚Äù Home skipper Rohit, who had dreamed of delivering his country‚Äôs first global trophy in 12 years amid stifling expectation, cut a hollow figure at the close. ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt our day, we tried everything but it wasn‚Äôt supposed to be,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe know that we were not good enough today but I‚Äôm really proud of how we‚Äôve played from game one. ‚ÄúWe kept losing wickets and couldn‚Äôt stitch up a big partnership, which is exactly what Australia did. Credit to Travis Head and Marnus Labuschagne, they stitched a big partnership and put us completely out of the game.‚Äù

newsArray.title: India vs Australia LIVE: Cricket World Cup final reaction after Travis Head century leads Aussies to victory
creator: Sonia Twigg and Ben Fleming
newsArray.description: Australia stunned hosts India to win the Cricket World Cup final by six wickets in Ahmedabad
newsArray.content: won a record-extending sixth title after opener to fashion their six-wicket victory in Sunday‚Äôs final against the tournament‚Äôs form team . Put into bat, India rode battling half-centuries by KL Rahul and to post a below-par 240 all out in exactly 50 overs at a packed Narendra Modi Stadium. Australia suffered a top-order wobble of their own but Head‚Äôs 137 off 120 balls saw them romp home with seven overs to spare in a match that never reached great heights. Around 93,000 predominantly Indian fans sat mostly in deathly silence as the home team, who had won 10 matches in a row to make the final, succumbed to their first loss of the tournament

newsArray.title: Mohammed Siraj Cries Inconsolably As India Suffer Heartbreaking Defeat To Australia In World Cup Final, Video Goes Viral
creator: ABP News Bureau
newsArray.description: Australia beat India by six wickets in the ICC Men's Cricket World Cup 2023 final at the Narendra Modi Stadium in Ahmedabad to claim their sixth World Cup title. While India came into the final as favourites, winning all their ten matches in a row, Australia, on the other hand, lost their first two matches before winning nine matches in a row including the final to go emerge as the World Champions.The defeat was difficult to digest especially because India had dominated every other opposition on their way to the final including Australia who they beat in their very first game. However, at the final frontier they fell short. The result was a heartbreak not only for fans but also for the players with Mohammed Siraj seen crying inconsolably post Australia's victory.The video of Siraj breaking down has gone viral on social media. Don't cry guys mohomad Siraj is crying üò≠ pic.twitter.com/ZPlg3LO6B0 ‚Äî CAM (@RMFC_CAM) November 19, 2023 Siraj Crying pic.twitter.com/57gVEUdzNP ‚Äî Abdul Ghaffar üáµüá∞ (@GhaffarDawnNews) November 19, 2023 India were asked to bat first and posted 240 riding on aggressive start from captain Rohit Sharma followed by half-centuries from Virat Kohli and KL Rahul who were cautious after India lost the wickets of Rohit and Shreyas Iyer in quick succession. In Australia's run chase, Mohammed Shami and Jasprit Bumrah took early wickets to reduce Australia to 47/3. However, a 192-run stand between Travis Head and Marnus Labuschagne took the match completely away from India and into the bag of Australia. Head scored a hundred, making 137 off 120, while Marnus Labuschagne remained unbeaten on 58 off 110, making sure he holds one end up while Head plays as the aggressor. The win means Australia beat India in a World Cup final for the second time after 2003. India's both defeats in World Cup finals have against the Men in Yellow with them managing to beat West Indies and Sri Lanka in 1983 and 2011 World Cup finals respectively.
newsArray.content: Australia beat India by six wickets in the ICC Men's Cricket World Cup 2023 final at the Narendra Modi Stadium in Ahmedabad to claim their sixth World Cup title. While India came into the final as favourites, winning all their ten matches in a row, Australia, on the other hand, lost their first two matches before winning nine matches in a row including the final to go emerge as the World Champions. The defeat was difficult to digest especially because India had dominated every other opposition on their way to the final including Australia who they beat in their very first game. However, at the final frontier they fell short. The result was a heartbreak not only for fans but also for the players with Mohammed Siraj seen crying inconsolably post Australia's victory. The video of Siraj breaking down has gone viral on social media. Don't cry guys mohomad Siraj is crying üò≠ pic.twitter.com/ZPlg3LO6B0 ‚Äî CAM (@RMFC_CAM) November 19, 2023 Siraj Crying pic.twitter.com/57gVEUdzNP googletag.cmd.push(function() { googletag.display("div-gpt-ad-6601185-5"); }); ‚Äî Abdul Ghaffar üáµüá∞ (@GhaffarDawnNews) November 19, 2023 India were asked to bat first and posted 240 riding on aggressive start from captain Rohit Sharma followed by half-centuries from Virat Kohli and KL Rahul who were cautious after India lost the wickets of Rohit and Shreyas Iyer in quick succession. In Australia's run chase, Mohammed Shami and Jasprit Bumrah took early wickets to reduce Australia to 47/3. However, a 192-run stand between Travis Head and Marnus Labuschagne took the match completely away from India and into the bag of Australia. Head scored a hundred, making 137 off 120, while Marnus Labuschagne remained unbeaten on 58 off 110, making sure he holds one end up while Head plays as the aggressor. The win means Australia beat India in a World Cup final for the second time after 2003. India's both defeats in World Cup finals have against the Men in Yellow with them managing to beat West Indies and Sri Lanka in 1983 and 2011 World Cup finals respectively.

newsArray.title: Australia stun India in World Cup Final
keywords: Australia stun India in World Cup Final
creator: sherrylynclarke@nationnews.com
newsArray.content: Ahmedabad ‚Äì Australia stunned hosts India in Ahmedabad to win the men‚Äôs Cricket World Cup for a sixth time. Australia quietened the wild support from the 100 000-strong home crowd by dismissing their previously unbeaten opponents for 240 before Travis Head‚Äôs sensational century meant they romped to victory with seven overs to spare. After their bowlers expertly took advantage of a slow pitch, Australia were themselves reduced to 47-three as India hit back in an electric new-ball spell. But Head and Marnus Labuschagne calmly weathered the storm with a stand of 192 as Indian hope drifted away from the world‚Äôs largest cricket stadium. Head was caught for 132 from 120 balls with just two runs needed, but Glenn Maxwell flogged the winning runs a ball later while Labuschagne ended 58 not out from 110. The superb victory means Australia extend their record as the most successful side in 50-over World Cup history and now sit four titles clear of the rest of the pack. It also caps a six-month period in which they beat India to win the World Test Championship and retained the Ashes in England. India, meanwhile, were left crestfallen as their bid for a first white-ball title since 2011 ‚Äì an achievement which looked unstoppable as they made rampant progress through the semi-final and group stage ‚Äì fell at the final hurdle. Summarised scores: India 240 all out in 50 overs: (KL Rahul 66, Virat Kohli 54; Mitchell Starc 3-55). Australia 241-4 in 43 overs (Travis Head 13, Marnus Labuschagne 58). Australia won by six wickets.

newsArray.title: Top of the mountain ‚Äì Pat Cummins hails Australia‚Äôs record sixth World Cup win
creator: Rory Dollard
newsArray.description: Travis Head‚Äôs brilliant 137 ensured Australia stunned hosts India in Ahmedabad.
newsArray.content: Triumphant captain basked in his side‚Äôs triumph over hosts , capping a remarkable year by reaching ‚Äúthe top of the mountain‚Äù. Australia arrived in Ahmedabad as underdogs, with the home side boasting a perfect record of 10 wins en route to the final, a monster crowd of over 110,000 roaring them on and familiar conditions. They even had the tournament‚Äôs top-scorer in and leading wicket-taker in Mohammed Shami, but to stand tall in knockout cricket. Travis Head took the starring role with a brilliant 137, making light work of India‚Äôs under-powered 240 all out, as a six-wicket win made his country six-time champions. It also capped a great year for Australia across red and white-ball cricket, having also pipped India to the World Test Championship crown in June and retained the Ashes with a 2-2 draw on English soil. Reflecting on a stunning sequence of results for his side, Cummins said: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs crazy. This year will be a year we remember for a long, long time. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been awesome. We‚Äôve pretty much spent the whole Australian winter away playing overseas but we‚Äôve had a lot of success and this pips it all. Top of the mountain. We saved our best for last. ‚ÄúThe passion in India is unrivalled around the world. Every single person here was wearing that blue shirt and whatever the result we were never going to forget a day like today.‚Äù Cummins had a fine day at the office. He made the bold and inspired decision to send a power-packed Indian batting line-up in after winning the toss and then produced a superb, boundary-less 10-over spell that included the key wicket of player-of-the-tournament Virat Kohli. But he was happy to give Head his moment in the limelight, as well as sharing with some of the backroom boys who helped him reach the final after he suffered a broken left hand. He was not fit until their fifth match of the tournament and was not even in India when Australia lost their first two group games. ‚ÄúTrav does what he does. He‚Äôs really brave, he takes the game on, puts pressure on bowlers and to do it on the biggest stage showed huge character,‚Äù Cummins said. ‚ÄúIt was amazing. We couldn‚Äôt be happier for Trav, he‚Äôs a legend and we love him‚Ä¶ how fun is he to watch? ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs also on the unheralded few, the selectors that backed him in even when he had a broken hand and the medical team to get him back out there. It was a big risk that we took and it paid off.‚Äù Head was struggling to take in the scale of his achievement, with each of his four sixes and 15 fours stamping down the hopes of the hordes of over a billion Indians. He had earlier taken a cracking over-the-shoulder catch to remove India skipper in full flow. ‚ÄúNot in a million years (could I have imagined this)‚Ä¶ what an amazing day. I‚Äôm thrilled to be part of it,‚Äù he told Sky Sports. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a lot better than sitting on the couch at home (injured). I was very lucky to get back here. ‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt imagine getting a hundred, I couldn‚Äôt imagine holding on to that catch‚Ä¶ but you want to help your team-mates and contribute so to do that on a big stage in front of a full house, under all that pressure, is something I‚Äôll be able to look back on all my life.‚Äù Home skipper Rohit, who had dreamed of delivering his country‚Äôs first global trophy in 12 years amid stifling expectation, cut a hollow figure at the close. ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt our day, we tried everything but it wasn‚Äôt supposed to be,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe know that we were not good enough today but I‚Äôm really proud of how we‚Äôve played from game one. ‚ÄúWe kept losing wickets and couldn‚Äôt stitch up a big partnership, which is exactly what Australia did. Credit to Travis Head and Marnus Labuschagne, they stitched a big partnership and put us completely out of the game.‚Äù

newsArray.title: Australia beats India to win Cricket World Cup for sixth time
newsArray.description: AHMEDABAD, NOVEMBER 19Australia won the Cricket World Cup for a record-extending sixth time Sunday, ending India's dominant run in its home tournament with a six-wicket victor...
newsArray.content: Australia won the Cricket World Cup for a record-extending sixth time Sunday, ending India's dominant run in its home tournament with a six-wicket victory in a low-scoring final on the back of Travis Head's 137. A heavily pro-Indian crowd inside the 132,000-capacity Narendra Modi Stadium was silenced as Head combined with Marnus Labuschagne (58 not out ) in a 192-run partnership to chase down the target of 241. Australia was wobbling on 47-3 after seven overs but Head and Labuschagne dug in to help their country regain its status as the king of one-day international cricket, adding to its 50-over world titles in 1987, 1999, 2003, 2007 and 2015. Head was dismissed off what proved to be the next-to-last ball of the match, caught in the deep while attempting to hit a title-clinching boundary. In came Glenn Maxwell and he ran two off his first ball, securing a victory that prompted fireworks above the world's largest cricket venue. The Indians won all 10 of their matches before the final and were seeking a third trophy in their fourth appearance in a title match that brought a country of 1.4 billion people to a virtual standstill. They were outplayed in every department by Australia, though, restricted to 240 all out on a slow pitch after losing the toss with only Virat Kohli (54) and Lokesh Rahul (66) making half-centuries. Head became only the seventh player to score a century in a men's World Cup final ‚Äì and third Australian after Ricky Ponting and Adam Gilchrist ‚Äì and delivered a significant moment in India's innings when taking a diving catch running back from cover to remove captain Rohit Sharma (47). Head's ton saw him join an illustrious list, which also comprises West Indies' Clive Lloyd and Viv Richards, as well as Sri Lanka's Aravinda de Silva and Mahela Jayawardene. Ponting's 140 not out had also helped Australia beat India in the 2003 final. Jayawardene's century is the only one in a losing cause with India winning the 2011 final. Australia finished the 2023 tournament with a run of nine straight wins, after starting with back-to-back defeats to India and South Africa. India won the World Cup in 1983 and 2011. Its last major success was winning the ICC Champions Trophy in 2013.

Reflecting on a stunning sequence of results for his side, Cummins said: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs crazy. This year will be a year we remember for a long, long time. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been awesome. We‚Äôve pretty much spent the whole Australian winter away playing overseas but we‚Äôve had a lot of success and this pips it all. Top of the mountain. We saved our best for last. ‚ÄúThe passion in India is unrivalled around the world. Every single person here was wearing that blue shirt and whatever the result we were never going to forget a day like today.‚Äù Cummins had a fine day at the office. He made the bold and inspired decision to send a power-packed Indian batting line-up in after winning the toss and then produced a superb, boundary-less 10-over spell that included the key wicket of player-of-the-tournament Virat Kohli. But he was happy to give Head his moment in the limelight, as well as sharing with some of the backroom boys who helped him reach the final after he suffered a broken left hand. He was not fit until their fifth match of the tournament and was not even in India when Australia lost their first two group games. ‚ÄúTrav does what he does. He‚Äôs really brave, he takes the game on, puts pressure on bowlers and to do it on the biggest stage showed huge character,‚Äù Cummins said. ‚ÄúIt was amazing. We couldn‚Äôt be happier for Trav, he‚Äôs a legend and we love him‚Ä¶ how fun is he to watch? ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs also on the unheralded few, the selectors that backed him in even when he had a broken hand and the medical team to get him back out there. It was a big risk that we took and it paid off.‚Äù Head was struggling to take in the scale of his achievement, with each of his four sixes and 15 fours stamping down the hopes of the hordes of over a billion Indians. He had earlier taken a cracking over-the-shoulder catch to remove India skipper Rohit Sharma in full flow. ‚ÄúNot in a million years (could I have imagined this)‚Ä¶ what an amazing day. I‚Äôm thrilled to be part of it,‚Äù he told Sky Sports. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a lot better than sitting on the couch at home (injured). I was very lucky to get back here. ‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt imagine getting a hundred, I couldn‚Äôt imagine holding on to that catch‚Ä¶ but you want to help your team-mates and contribute so to do that on a big stage in front of a full house, under all that pressure, is something I‚Äôll be able to look back on all my life.‚Äù Home skipper Rohit, who had dreamed of delivering his country‚Äôs first global trophy in 12 years amid stifling expectation, cut a hollow figure at the close. ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt our day, we tried everything but it wasn‚Äôt supposed to be,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe know that we were not good enough today but I‚Äôm really proud of how we‚Äôve played from game one. ‚ÄúWe kept losing wickets and couldn‚Äôt stitch up a big partnership, which is exactly what Australia did. Credit to Travis Head and Marnus Labuschagne, they stitched a big partnership and put us completely out of the game.‚Äù

newsArray.description: Australia stunned hosts India to win the Cricket World Cup final by six wickets in Ahmedabad
newsArray.content: won a record-extending sixth title after opener to fashion their six-wicket victory in Sunday‚Äôs final against the tournament‚Äôs form team . Put into bat, India rode battling half-centuries by KL Rahul and to post a below-par 240 all out in exactly 50 overs at a packed Narendra Modi Stadium. Australia suffered a top-order wobble of their own but Head‚Äôs 137 off 120 balls saw them romp home with seven overs to spare in a match that never reached great heights. newsArray.title: Australia stun India in World Cup Final
keywords: Australia stun India in World Cup Final
creator: sherrylynclarke@nationnews.com
newsArray.content: Ahmedabad ‚Äì Australia stunned hosts India in Ahmedabad to win the men‚Äôs Cricket World Cup for a sixth time. Australia quietened the wild support from the 100 000-strong home crowd by dismissing their previously unbeaten opponents for 240 before Travis Head‚Äôs sensational century meant they romped to victory with seven overs to spare. After their bowlers expertly took advantage of a slow pitch, Australia were themselves reduced to 47-three as India hit back in an electric new-ball spell. But Head and Marnus Labuschagne calmly weathered the storm with a stand of 192 as Indian hope drifted away from the world‚Äôs largest cricket stadium. Head was caught for 132 from 120 balls with just two runs needed, but Glenn Maxwell flogged the winning runs a ball later while Labuschagne ended 58 not out from 110. The superb victory means Australia extend their record as the most successful side in 50-over World Cup history and now sit four titles clear of the rest of the pack. It also caps a six-month period in which they beat India to win the World Test Championship and retained the Ashes in England. India, meanwhile, were left crestfallen as their bid for a first white-ball title since 2011 ‚Äì an achievement which looked unstoppable as they made rampant progress through the semi-final and group stage ‚Äì fell at the final hurdle. Summarised scores: India 240 all out in 50 overs: (KL Rahul 66, Virat Kohli 54; Mitchell Starc 3-55). Australia 241-4 in 43 overs (Travis Head 13, Marnus Labuschagne 58). Australia won by six wickets.

newsArray.title: Australia beats India to win Cricket World Cup for sixth time
newsArray.description: AHMEDABAD, NOVEMBER 19Australia won the Cricket World Cup for a record-extending sixth time Sunday, ending India's dominant run in its home tournament with a six-wicket victor...
newsArray.content: Australia won the Cricket World Cup for a record-extending sixth time Sunday, ending India's dominant run in its home tournament with a six-wicket victory in a low-scoring final on the back of Travis Head's 137. A heavily pro-Indian crowd inside the 132,000-capacity Narendra Modi Stadium was silenced as Head combined with Marnus Labuschagne (58 not out ) in a 192-run partnership to chase down the target of 241. Australia was wobbling on 47-3 after seven overs but Head and Labuschagne dug in to help their country regain its status as the king of one-day international cricket, adding to its 50-over world titles in 1987, 1999, 2003, 2007 and 2015. Head was dismissed off what proved to be the next-to-last ball of the match, caught in the deep while attempting to hit a title-clinching boundary. In came Glenn Maxwell and he ran two off his first ball, securing a victory that prompted fireworks above the world's largest cricket venue. The Indians won all 10 of their matches before the final and were seeking a third trophy in their fourth appearance in a title match that brought a country of 1.4 billion people to a virtual standstill. They were outplayed in every department by Australia, though, restricted to 240 all out on a slow pitch after losing the toss with only Virat Kohli (54) and Lokesh Rahul (66) making half-centuries. Head became only the seventh player to score a century in a men's World Cup final ‚Äì and third Australian after Ricky Ponting and Adam Gilchrist ‚Äì and delivered a significant moment in India's innings when taking a diving catch running back from cover to remove captain Rohit Sharma (47). Head's ton saw him join an illustrious list, which also comprises West Indies' Clive Lloyd and Viv Richards, as well as Sri Lanka's Aravinda de Silva and Mahela Jayawardene. Ponting's 140 not out had also helped Australia beat India in the 2003 final. Jayawardene's century is the only one in a losing cause with India winning the 2011 final. Australia finished the 2023 tournament with a run of nine straight wins, after starting with back-to-back defeats to India and South Africa. India won the World Cup in 1983 and 2011. Its last major success was winning the ICC Champions Trophy in 2013.

We couldn‚Äôt be happier for Trav, he‚Äôs a legend and we love him‚Ä¶ how fun is he to watch? ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs also on the unheralded few, the selectors that backed him in even when he had a broken hand and the medical team to get him back out there. It was a big risk that we took and it paid off.‚Äù Head was struggling to take in the scale of his achievement, with each of his four sixes and 15 fours stamping down the hopes of the hordes of over a billion Indians. He had earlier taken a cracking over-the-shoulder catch to remove India skipper Rohit Sharma in full flow. ‚ÄúNot in a million years (could I have imagined this)‚Ä¶ what an amazing day. I was very lucky to get back here. ‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt imagine getting a hundred, I couldn‚Äôt imagine holding on to that catch‚Ä¶ but you want to help your team-mates and contribute so to do that on a big stage in front of a full house, under all that pressure, is something I‚Äôll be able to look back on all my life.‚Äù Home skipper Rohit, who had dreamed of delivering his country‚Äôs first global trophy in 12 years amid stifling expectation, cut a hollow figure at the close. ‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt our day, we tried everything but it wasn‚Äôt supposed to be,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe know that we were not good enough today but I‚Äôm really proud of how we‚Äôve played from game one. ‚ÄúWe kept losing wickets and couldn‚Äôt stitch up a big partnership, which is exactly what Australia did. They even had the tournament‚Äôs top-scorer in Virat Kohli and leading wicket-taker in Mohammed Shami, but were unable to match Australia‚Äôs ability to stand tall in knockout cricket. Travis Head took the starring role with a brilliant 137, making light work of India‚Äôs under-powered 240 all out, as a six-wicket win made his country six-time champions. It also capped a great year for Australia across red and white-ball cricket, having also pipped India to the World Test Championship crown in June and retained the Ashes with a 2-2 draw on English soil. Reflecting on a stunning sequence of results for his side, Cummins said: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs crazy. This year will be a year we remember for a long, long time. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been awesome. We saved our best for last. ‚ÄúThe passion in India is unrivalled around the world. Every single person here was wearing that blue shirt and whatever the result we were never going to forget a day like today.‚Äù Cummins had a fine day at the office. He made the bold and inspired decision to send a power-packed Indian batting line-up in after winning the toss and then produced a superb, boundary-less 10-over spell that included the key wicket of player-of-the-tournament Virat Kohli. newsArray.title: India vs Australia LIVE: Cricket World Cup final reaction after Travis Head century leads Aussies to victory
creator: Sonia Twigg and Ben Fleming
newsArray.description: Australia stunned hosts India to win the Cricket World Cup final by six wickets in Ahmedabad
newsArray.content: won a record-extending sixth title after opener to fashion their six-wicket victory in Sunday‚Äôs final against the tournament‚Äôs form team . Put into bat, India rode battling half-centuries by KL Rahul and to post a below-par 240 all out in exactly 50 overs at a packed Narendra Modi Stadium. Australia suffered a top-order wobble of their own but Head‚Äôs 137 off 120 balls saw them romp home with seven overs to spare in a match that never reached great heights. Around 93,000 predominantly Indian fans sat mostly in deathly silence as the home team, who had won 10 matches in a row to make the final, succumbed to their first loss of the tournament

newsArray.title: Mohammed Siraj Cries Inconsolably As India Suffer Heartbreaking Defeat To Australia In World Cup Final, Video Goes Viral
creator: ABP News Bureau
newsArray.description: Australia beat India by six wickets in the ICC Men's Cricket World Cup 2023 final at the Narendra Modi Stadium in Ahmedabad to claim their sixth World Cup title. While India came into the final as favourites, winning all their ten matches in a row, Australia, on the other hand, lost their first two matches before winning nine matches in a row including the final to go emerge as the World Champions.The defeat was difficult to digest especially because India had dominated every other opposition on their way to the final including Australia who they beat in their very first game. However, at the final frontier they fell short. The result was a heartbreak not only for fans but also for the players with Mohammed Siraj seen crying inconsolably post Australia's victory.The video of Siraj breaking down has gone viral on social media. Don't cry guys mohomad Siraj is crying üò≠ pic.twitter.com/ZPlg3LO6B0 ‚Äî CAM (@RMFC_CAM) November 19, 2023 Siraj Crying pic.twitter.com/57gVEUdzNP ‚Äî Abdul Ghaffar üáµüá∞ (@GhaffarDawnNews) November 19, 2023 India were asked to bat first and posted 240 riding on aggressive start from captain Rohit Sharma followed by half-centuries from Virat Kohli and KL Rahul who were cautious after India lost the wickets of Rohit and Shreyas Iyer in quick succession. In Australia's run chase, Mohammed Shami and Jasprit Bumrah took early wickets to reduce Australia to 47/3. However, a 192-run stand between Travis Head and Marnus Labuschagne took the match completely away from India and into the bag of Australia. Head scored a hundred, making 137 off 120, while Marnus Labuschagne remained unbeaten on 58 off 110, making sure he holds one end up while Head plays as the aggressor. The win means Australia beat India in a World Cup final for the second time after 2003. India's both defeats in World Cup finals have against the Men in Yellow with them managing to beat West Indies and Sri Lanka in 1983 and 2011 World Cup finals respectively.

newsArray.title: Australia stun India in World Cup Final
keywords: Australia stun India in World Cup Final
creator: sherrylynclarke@nationnews.com
newsArray.content: Ahmedabad ‚Äì Australia stunned hosts India in Ahmedabad to win the men‚Äôs Cricket World Cup for a sixth time. Australia quietened the wild support from the 100 000-strong home crowd by dismissing their previously unbeaten opponents for 240 before Travis Head‚Äôs sensational century meant they romped to victory with seven overs to spare. After their bowlers expertly took advantage of a slow pitch, Australia were themselves reduced to 47-three as India hit back in an electric new-ball spell. But Head and Marnus Labuschagne calmly weathered the storm with a stand of 192 as Indian hope drifted away from the world‚Äôs largest cricket stadium. Head was caught for 132 from 120 balls with just two runs needed, but Glenn Maxwell flogged the winning runs a ball later while Labuschagne ended 58 not out from 110. The superb victory means Australia extend their record as the most successful side in 50-over World Cup history and now sit four titles clear of the rest of the pack. It also caps a six-month period in which they beat India to win the World Test Championship and retained the Ashes in England. India, meanwhile, were left crestfallen as their bid for a first white-ball title since 2011 ‚Äì an achievement which looked unstoppable as they made rampant progress through the semi-final and group stage ‚Äì fell at the final hurdle. Summarised scores: India 240 all out in 50 overs: (KL Rahul 66, Virat Kohli 54; Mitchell Starc 3-55). Australia 241-4 in 43 overs (Travis Head 13, Marnus Labuschagne 58). Australia won by six wickets.
